Hello there #design of Zulip!

An organization I am part of has tried Zulip for week last month. Although we liked Zulip's information architecture from users' perspective quite a lot, sadly we decided not to change our main chat platform just yet.

The most difficult moment of this experiment was our first day, when we (>100ppl) had to confront the unconventionality of the Zulip's UI.
I tried to make it easier for myself and my colleagues and received quite a positive feedback on this custom css here.

There are three main aspects it tackles:

  1. Poor legibility – less dense, more contrasting typography gives more definition to each semantic element: titles, messages, reactions, quotes etc and difference between them

  2. Feeling of being overwhelmed – removed indication of continuity of the stream, hovered messages, greyed out quoted text, use of bg instead of borders to highlight information where possible, other accents help to focus on reading the current message instead of being reminded of the whole context all the time

  3. "Outdated" "look and feel" – rounded corners, thinner borders, typography

I hope you could try it out and consider these points as improvement suggestions very much as I personally miss Zulip's features quite a lot :new_moon_face:
Thanks for sharing the CSS. I'm giving it a spin! :slight_smile:

I like this look of night mode :sweat_smile:
This is brilliant. (I hope I'll get a chance to play around with it soon.)
@Trent Lapinski You might find this thread interesting.

I don't use the webapp much, and perhaps streams do sort of translate into them, but what I assume are stream markers look a little too much just like 'tags'? I mean, clicking on a 'tag' does go to everything with that 'tag', but I'm not sure if it will all translate in the way people expect?
Interesting to see the background color approach for active message - it's not quite the same, but historically in ZT we've tended towards background-highlight instead of border.
I'm definitely liking this direction. Those are all teething points we should keep exploring. I like the more modern looking rounded corners, nightmode, etc.
Yeah, there are a lot of aspects of this design that feel really nice. Thank you, Sveta Goldstein, for sharing!

I really like the compose box, it feels less stuck on an more like it belongs. And I like using background color rather than borders. The spacing is subtle, but I think it gives much.

I'm not too fond of the stream indicator. I seem to have developed some Stockholm syndrome in regard to the current implementation. And I miss the color of the stream following the topic down. I think the change in color of the left border is a good visual reminder that one is switching context from one stream to another.
Looks great! I know people mention Zulip's UI looks old (I don't personally mind it), is there any large visual refresh in the works?

Some promising positive early feedback:

Got to say, I like the Zulip UI refresh. It's not huge, but it is a 100% improvement and that is really hard to do
